title: 31 years after man was kidnapped, CBI court sends former Punjab Police officer to 10 years in jail
selftext: A chargesheet was filed against both the accused persons on September 16, 1999.
comments:
A special court of the Central Bureau of Investigation (CBI) on Saturday sentenced a former Punjab Police officer to ten years of rigorous imprisonment (RI) in a 31-year-old case of kidnapping. The court also imposed a fine of Rs. 1 lakh, failure to pay which will lead to one-year additional jail term.

The court of special CBI judge Manjot Kaur convicted Amarjit Singh, the then SHO posted at Jhabal police station in Tarn Taran district under Section 120-B (criminal conspiracy) read with 364 (kidnapping) of the Indian Penal Code (IPC).

Accused Ashok Kumar, the then DSP, died during the trial and proceedings against him were abated. A chargesheet was filed against both the accused persons on September 16, 1999.

The case

On October 4, 1992, the police, led by Singh and Kumar, picked up two women, Rajwant Kaur and her mother-in-law Gurbachan Kaur. On the same day, Rajwant’s husband Balwinder Singh was also picked up. The police had alleged that Balwinder has ties with terrorists.

After keeping Rajwant and Gurbachan at the Jhabhal police station for a few days, the police released the two women. Meanwhile, Balwinder was taken to Ferozepur. Ever since, nobody knows about the whereabouts of Balwinder, the CBI said.

On November 15, 1996, the Supreme Court directed the CBI to conduct a preliminary inquiry into the cremation of large scale unclaimed dead bodies in three districts of Punjab. The CBI subsequently submitted its report before the apex court and on December 12, 1996, the investigation into the matter was entrusted to the CBI.

The CBI recorded Rajwant’s statement during a preliminary inquiry and thereafter, registered a regular case on February 27, 1997. The CBI completed the investigation and filed a charge sheet in 1999 and charges were framed in 2000 but the trial remained stayed from 2002 to 2022 on the basis of petitions of the accused which were dismissed later.
